snippet: The court found that possibly exculpatory evidence was unfairly suppressed in the trial of Richard Lapointe, whose conviction drew attention from celebrities and advocates for the disabled.
abstract: Connecticut Appellate Court orders a new trial for Richard Lapointe, who was convicted of arson, rape and murder and sentenced to life in prison in 1987, saying that Lapointe did not get a fair trial because the state suppressed a report from fire marshals that could have bolstered his alibi.
lead_paragraph: The court found that possibly exculpatory evidence was unfairly suppressed in the trial of Richard Lapointe, whose conviction drew attention from celebrities and advocates for the disabled.

headline.seo: Connecticut Court Grants Retrial for Richard Lapointe in 1987 Murder
headline.main: Connecticut Court Orders Retrial for Man Convicted in ’87 Murder
headline.print_headline: Connecticut Court Orders Retrial for Man Convicted in ’87 Rape, Arson and Murder
